g.text: pressurizing O and Ca cations ﬁrstly arrange into close packing
assembly consisting both of distorted HCP and CCP elements
(with P and Be occupying tetrahedral and trigonal bipyramidal
voids in hurlbutite-II and -III) and later into ABCA-
CABCBCAB arrangement (with P and Be ﬁlling octahedral voids
in hurlbutite-IV). While the cation coordination and oxygen
sublattice are traditional determinants of a crystal structure, the
alternative view on the crystal chemistry of oxides was proposed
by O’Keeffe and Hyde by introducing terms cation packing and
. While this approach was found to be
effective for a number of cases (e.g., elaborating on Al coordi-
transition), we ﬁnd that the classical way of structure repre-
sentation is more appropriate for our cases. By studying high-
pressure behavior of a group of isotopological compounds with
we conclude that the crystal structure response (and particularly
species) is governed by interplay of two factors:
tetrahedra and size of large M cation. The
chemistry of the T site governs T[IV]
(e.g., compare Be[V] and P[V] between 70–75 and 82–85 GPa in
, respectively, and Si[V] at c.a. 22 GPa in CaB
). The size of the M cation is responsible for formation of
close packing arrangement with trigonal bipyramidal voids, i.e.,
species. Thus, in contrast to CaB
does not change coordination to ﬁve-fold
upon pressurizing but instead undergoes a splitting into two
. Further increase of M cation size results in complete
absence of Si[V]: the high-pressure polymorphism is realized via
Si[VI] transition in the crystal structure of
. In the upcoming review article on high-pressure
compounds we are going to elaborate on
the crystal chemical regularities in detail.
The present study further proves the powerful capabilities of
high pressure as a tool for tuning chemical properties of matter.
Growing interest of the chemical community in high-pressure
SCXRD techniques using diamond anvil cells (DACs) ensures
that the upcoming studies will bring further examples of unique
phases as well as provide a solid experimental basis for the future
development of novel high-pressure crystal chemistry.
, originating from Viitaniemi pegmatite (Eräjärvi area, Orivesi, Western
Museum, CeNak, University of Hamburg. Three separate in situ high-pressure
SCXRD were performed at the experimental station P02.2 (extreme conditions
beamline) at synchrotron Petra III (Hamburg, Germany). Symmetric DACs with
culets diameter of 300, 200, and 150 μm were used for pressure generation in
, respectively. The sample chambers with approximate
diameters of 150, 100, and 85 μm were obtained by drilling the preindented rhe-
nium gasket. Hurlbutite crystals were placed inside the sample chambers along
with a ruby sphere for pressure estimation (Supplementary Fig. 10)
were loaded with neon as pressure-transmitting medium using the in-house gas
loading system at Petra III. Monochromatic X-ray diffraction experiments were
performed using X-rays with wavelength of ~0.2905 Å. The X-ray beam was
focused to less than 10 × 10 μm by Kirkpatrick–Baez mirrors for experiments #
and by Compound Reﬂective Lenses for experiment #
patterns were collected using Perkin Elmer detector. Before each experiment the
detector-sample distance was calibrated with a CeO
At each pressure both a wide-scan and a stepped ω-scan were collected for each
crystal. Wide scans consisted of 40 s exposures during rotations of ±20° of the
DAC. Step scans consisted of individual exposures taken over 0.5° intervals to
angle of maximum intensity of each peak. Collected diffraction
images were analyzed using the program CrysAlis Pro
package was used for all structural determinations
behavior of hurlbutite has been followed up to 91 GPa by performing SCXRD
experiments at every pressure step of 3–5 GPa. In total 26 high-pressure structural
reﬁnements have been performed, the representative ones are given in
. Calculations of the electronic structure, total energies
and structural parameters for all phases of hurlbutite were performed in the fra-
mework of the DFT using the Vienna ab initio simulation package
interaction between ions and electrons were described using the projector
through recommended potentials for Ca, Be, P and
O. A plane-wave basis set cutoff energy was set to 600 eV. The generalized gradient
was selected to treat the exchange and correlation effects. PBE-GGA belongs to the
so-called semilocal DFT functionals, which are known to slightly underestimate
bonding strength in solids and signiﬁcantly underestimate band gaps in semi-
cinductors and insulators. However, it is numerically efﬁcient and provides accu-
racy, which is sufﬁcient for the purposes of the present study. The integration over
the Brillouin zone was performed using a gamma-centered mesh with a k-points
grid 6 × 6 × 6. All the calculations were carried out using the Gaussian smearing
0.05 eV. All properties were calculated at a given volumes
(pressures) after the ion positions and cell shape were relaxed to achieve forces
The X-ray crystallographic coordinates for structures reported in this article have been
deposited at the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database (ICSD) under deposition numbers
CSD 1913366-1913370. These data can be obtained from CCDC’s and FIZ Karlsruhe’s
free service for viewing and retrieving structures (

17. Plonka, A. M. et al. β-diopside, a new ultrahigh-pressure polymorph of
18. Hu, Y., Kiefer, B., Bina, C. R., Zhang, D. & Dera, P. K. High-pressure
: does penta-coordinated silicon exist in the earth’s mantle?
19. Pakhomova, A. et al. A closer look into close packing: pentacoordinated
silicon in a high-pressure polymorph of danburite.
20. Pakhomova, A. et al. A new high-pressure phase transition in clinoferrosilite:
in situ single-crystal X-ray diffraction study.
